items.title: The shutdown is over, but some effects will linger
items.standfirst: After the longest shutdown in history, the House passed a bill last night to fund the government through Jan. 30, and President Trump signed it, reopening the federal government, which had been shut since Oct. 1. The deal to resume government functions came together after eight Democratic senators…
items.content: After the longest shutdown in history, the House passed a bill last night to fund the government through Jan. 30, and President Trump signed it, reopening the federal government, which had been shut since Oct. 1. The deal to resume government functions came together after eight Democratic senators…

items.title: These 6 House Democrats voted for bill to end government shutdown
items.standfirst: The funding package that ended the longest government shutdown in modern U.S. history picked up support from a half-dozen Democrats — mostly moderates who represent competitive districts — when it passed the House late Wednesday.
items.content: The funding package that ended the longest government shutdown in modern U.S. history picked up support from a half-dozen Democrats — mostly moderates who represent competitive districts — when it passed the House late Wednesday.

items.title: Asia-Pacific stocks edge mostly higher as U.S. House passes funding bill to end shutdown
items.standfirst: Asia-Pacific shares mostly rose Thursday after U.S. President Donald Trump signed a funding bill into law, effectively ending the longest federal government shutdown in U.S. history. Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.13%, while the Topix added 0.62% to hit a record high. Shares of SoftBank…

items.content: President Trump signed a government funding package at the White House late Wednesday, formally ending the longest government shutdown in U.S. history.

items.title: Jeffries says the "fight is not over" on health care
items.standfirst: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries told CBS News that Democrats will still press to extend a slate of expiring health insurance subsidies after the 43-day-long shutdown.
items.content: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries told CBS News that Democrats will still press to extend a slate of expiring health insurance subsidies after the 43-day-long shutdown.

items.title: SNAP benefits likely to resume quickly after shutdown ends, experts say
items.standfirst: A government funding package signed by President Trump on Wednesday will reopen federal agencies, opening the door for food-stamp recipients to collect their full benefits.
items.content: A government funding package signed by President Trump on Wednesday will reopen federal agencies, opening the door for food-stamp recipients to collect their full benefits.

items.title: How the longest government shutdown in history came to an end
items.standfirst: After 43 days and more than a dozen attempts to reopen the government, President Trump signed the funding package, passed by the Senate and House, into law.
items.content: After 43 days and more than a dozen attempts to reopen the government, President Trump signed the funding package, passed by the Senate and House, into law.

items.title: House passes funding bill to end US shutdown – see how lawmakers voted
items.standfirst: Bill passes House with with 222 in favor and 209 against. Here’s how Republicans and Democrats votedThe US House of Representatives voted to pass the funding bill to end the longest government shutdown in US history. Trump signed the bill into law on Wednesday night.The legislation comes in the wake of a Senate-brokered compromise in which a handful of Democrats voted toforego the extension of expiring healthcare subsidies, which have been at the heart of the long impasse. The bill extends government funding at current levels through January. Three year-long provisions, which fund programs at the Department of Veterans Affairs, the USDA and FDA, and legislative branch operations, are also included. Continue reading...
items.content: Bill passes House with with 222 in favor and 209 against. Here’s how Republicans and Democrats votedThe US House of Representatives voted to pass the funding bill to end the longest government shutdown in US history. Trump signed the bill into law on Wednesday night.The legislation comes in the wake of a Senate-brokered compromise in which a handful of Democrats voted toforego the extension of expiring healthcare subsidies, which have been at the heart of the long impasse. The bill extends government funding at current levels through January. Three year-long provisions, which fund programs at the Department of Veterans Affairs, the USDA and FDA, and legislative branch operations, are also included. Continue reading...

items.content: President Donald Trump signed a bill passed by the House and Senate to end the longest-ever shutdown, effectively reopening the government.

items.title: Speaker Mike Johnson calls shutdown "utterly pointless" after House passes funding bill
items.standfirst: House Speaker Mike Johnson addressed reporters on Wednesday night after the lower chamber voted to pass a Senate-backed funding package to end the 43-day government shutdown, the longest in U.S. history. Johnson admonished Democrats over the impasse and touted Republicans' achievements in the first 10 months of President Trump's second term.
items.content: House Speaker Mike Johnson addressed reporters on Wednesday night after the lower chamber voted to pass a Senate-backed funding package to end the 43-day government shutdown, the longest in U.S. history. Johnson admonished Democrats over the impasse and touted Republicans' achievements in the first 10 months of President Trump's second term.

items.title: Trump signs bill ending record-breaking 43-day US government shutdown
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Wednesday signed legislation to end the longest government shutdown in US history, restoring funding to federal agencies and pay to hundreds of thousands of workers after a 43-day lapse that disrupted essential services across the country.
items.content: President Donald Trump on Wednesday signed legislation to end the longest government shutdown in US history, restoring funding to federal agencies and pay to hundreds of thousands of workers after a 43-day lapse that disrupted essential services across the country.

items.title: Hakeem Jeffries blames Trump and Republicans for government shutdown before House vote
items.standfirst: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries spoke as the House debated the Senate's version of a bill to fund the government and end the shutdown.
items.content: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries spoke as the House debated the Senate's version of a bill to fund the government and end the shutdown.

items.title: Trump signs spending bill to end longest US gov’t shutdown in history
items.standfirst: The House of Representatives passed the much-delayed bill hours earlier.
items.content: The House of Representatives passed the much-delayed bill hours earlier.

items.title: House passes bill to fund government and end shutdown
items.standfirst: The House passed a funding bill to end the government shutdown on Wednesday night, sending the measure to President Trump's desk for final signature. CBS News congressional reporter Taurean Small has the latest.
items.content: The House passed a funding bill to end the government shutdown on Wednesday night, sending the measure to President Trump's desk for final signature. CBS News congressional reporter Taurean Small has the latest.

items.title: Mike Johnson says Democrats knew the shutdown "would cause pain, and they did it anyway"

items.content: House Speaker Mike Johnson criticized Democrats for their handling of the government shutdown before lawmakers put the funding bill up for a vote.

items.title: The longest government shutdown in U.S. history comes to a close
items.standfirst: President Trump signed a bill to fund the government through the end of January, ending the shutdown that has dragged on for six weeks.
items.content: President Trump signed a bill to fund the government through the end of January, ending the shutdown that has dragged on for six weeks. (Image credit: BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI)

items.title: Hakeem Jeffries addresses backlash to shutdown deal, standing against Trump and more
items.standfirst: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries discusses backlash among Democrats over a deal to end the government shutdown without extending health care subsidies, standing up to President Trump's agenda and more in this extended interview with "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson.
items.content: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries discusses backlash among Democrats over a deal to end the government shutdown without extending health care subsidies, standing up to President Trump's agenda and more in this extended interview with "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson.

items.title: Rep. Suzan DelBene says "Democrats are standing up"
items.standfirst: Lawmakers in the House of Representatives are set to vote on a measure to end the longest-ever government shutdown. The funding fight has exposed an apparent rift between Democrats. Democratic Rep. Suzan DelBene of Washington joins CBS News to discuss.
items.content: Lawmakers in the House of Representatives are set to vote on a measure to end the longest-ever government shutdown. The funding fight has exposed an apparent rift between Democrats. Democratic Rep. Suzan DelBene of Washington joins CBS News to discuss.

items.title: Republican Rep. Marlin Stutzman says "Democrats made a huge mistake" over the government shutdown
items.standfirst: The House of Representatives is expected to vote on a funding bill on Wednesday to end the longest government shutdown in American history. Republican Rep. Marlin Stutzman of Indiana joins CBS News to discuss.
items.content: The House of Representatives is expected to vote on a funding bill on Wednesday to end the longest government shutdown in American history. Republican Rep. Marlin Stutzman of Indiana joins CBS News to discuss.

items.title: Essay: What comes next after the shutdown ends
items.standfirst: As lawmakers prepare to vote on a deal to end the government shutdown, "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson asks, what should the government do about the problems it illuminated?
items.content: As lawmakers prepare to vote on a deal to end the government shutdown, "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson asks, what should the government do about the problems it illuminated?

ai_summary: The House passed a bill to fund the government through January 30, ending the shutdown.
President Trump signed the bill, reopening the federal government after 43 days.
The funding deal was reached after eight Democratic senators supported the bill.
Asia-Pacific stocks mostly rose after the bill was signed into law.
House Speaker Johnson expects repeal of a phone records rule from the funding bill.

items.title: White House calls Epstein emails release a Democratic smear
items.standfirst: Jeffrey Epstein wrote in a 2019 email to a journalist that Donald Trump “knew about the girls," according to documents made public Wednesday, but what he knew — and whether it pertained to the sex offender’s crimes — is unclear. The White House quickly accused Democrats of selectively leaking the emails to smear the president. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis has more.

items.content: The White House says emails from sex offender Jeffrey Epstein about President Trump “prove absolutely nothing."

FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.

clusters.title: Ukraine justice, energy ministers resign over major corruption scandal
clusters.neutral_headline: Ukraine Ministers Resign Amid Corruption Scandal

items.title: Ukraine justice, energy ministers resign over major corruption scandal
items.standfirst: Ukraine's energy and justice ministers resigned on Wednesday, the government said, over their alleged involvement in a sweeping corruption scandal in the country's energy sector. Investigators alleged a key ally of President Volodymyr Zelensky orchestrated a $100-million kickback scheme to siphon off funds, triggering public anger at a time of widespread power outages caused by Russian attacks.
items.content: Ukraine's energy and justice ministers resigned on Wednesday, the government said, over their alleged involvement in a sweeping corruption scandal in the country's energy sector. Investigators alleged a key ally of President Volodymyr Zelensky orchestrated a $100-million kickback scheme to siphon off funds, triggering public anger at a time of widespread power outages caused by Russian attacks.

items.title: Ukraine ministers toppled amid embezzlement and kickbacks scandal
items.standfirst: Ukraine's justice and energy ministers have resigned amid a major embezzlement and kickbacks scandal involving the state nuclear power company.
items.content: Ukraine's justice and energy ministers have resigned amid a major embezzlement and kickbacks scandal involving the state nuclear power company.

items.title: ‘Absolutely unacceptable’: Zelenskyy condemns corruption in energy sector targeted by Russia
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he had suspended the justice and energy ministers, pending an investigation into a $100 million kickback scandal centered on the country’s embattled energy sector.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he had suspended the justice and energy ministers, pending an investigation into a $100 million kickback scandal centered on the country’s embattled energy sector.

items.content: The Ukrainian president has called for the justice and energy ministers to be removed from their posts.

items.title: $100M corruption scandal rocks Ukraine and embroils top Zelenskyy ally

items.content: Ukraine Justice Minister German Galushchenko was suspended in a corruption probe into state energy company Energoatom that includes Zelenskyy ally Timur Mindich.

ai_summary: Ukraine's energy and justice ministers resigned due to a corruption scandal.
The scandal involves a $100 million kickback scheme in the energy sector.
A key ally of President Zelenskyy is alleged to have orchestrated the scheme.
Zelenskyy has condemned the corruption and suspended the ministers.
The scandal has triggered public anger amid power outages.

items.title: Kim Kardashian's shapewear brand Skims hits $5bn valuation
items.standfirst: The company says it plans to open more physical shops and expand the business around the world.
items.content: The company says it plans to open more physical shops and expand the business around the world.

items.title: Kim Kardashian’s Skims valued at $5bn after raising new funding
items.standfirst: Skims plans to use new capital to broaden its intimates lines, and expand further into apparel and activewear Skims, founded by reality TV star and entrepreneur Kim Kardashian along with CEO Jens Grede, said on Wednesday it had raised $225m in new capital, valuing the shapewear label at $5bn.Kardashian’s ventures, including her cosmetics brand SKKN, have attracted young shoppers and benefited from her vast social media following. Similarly, other celebrity-backed brands have also drawn venture capital investment, as firms bet on the marketing power and built-in audiences of high-profile founders to drive consumer demand. Continue reading...
items.content: Skims plans to use new capital to broaden its intimates lines, and expand further into apparel and activewear Skims, founded by reality TV star and entrepreneur Kim Kardashian along with CEO Jens Grede, said on Wednesday it had raised $225m in new capital, valuing the shapewear label at $5bn.Kardashian’s ventures, including her cosmetics brand SKKN, have attracted young shoppers and benefited from her vast social media following. Similarly, other celebrity-backed brands have also drawn venture capital investment, as firms bet on the marketing power and built-in audiences of high-profile founders to drive consumer demand. The brand's success is attributed to Kardashian's social media presence.
Other celebrity-backed brands have also attracted venture capital investment.

clusters.title: French relief as Algeria frees jailed novelist at centre of diplomatic crisis
clusters.neutral_headline: Algeria Frees Jailed Novelist Boualem Sansal

items.title: French relief as Algeria frees jailed novelist at centre of diplomatic crisis
items.standfirst: Almost a year to the day after Boualem Sansal was arrested, the Algerian president grants him a pardon.
items.content: Almost a year to the day after Boualem Sansal was arrested, the Algerian president grants him a pardon.

items.title: Pardoned French-Algerian dissident writer Sansal en route to Germany
items.standfirst: Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune has granted a pardon to French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal following a request from German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the Algerian presidency said on Wednesday. Algerian authorities arrested Sansal a year ago and a court sentenced him in March to five years in jail for 'undermining national unity'.
items.content: Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune has granted a pardon to French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal following a request from German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the Algerian presidency said on Wednesday. Algerian authorities arrested Sansal a year ago and a court sentenced him in March to five years in jail for 'undermining national unity'.

items.title: French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal pardoned and to be released from prison
items.standfirst: Eighty-one year-old, who has prostate cancer, can now be transferred from Algeria to Germany for medical treatmentThe French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal has been pardoned and is to be released from prison, the Algerian presidential office said in a statement on Wednesday.The move, which will mean Sansal can be transferred to Germany for medical treatment, comes after the German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Algeria to free Sansal. Continue reading...
items.content: Eighty-one year-old, who has prostate cancer, can now be transferred from Algeria to Germany for medical treatmentThe French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal has been pardoned and is to be released from prison, the Algerian presidential office said in a statement on Wednesday.The move, which will mean Sansal can be transferred to Germany for medical treatment, comes after the German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Algeria to free Sansal. Continue reading...

items.title: Algeria pardons French-Algerian author Sansal after year-long imprisonment
items.standfirst: Algeria ’s president granted a humanitarian pardon to the French-Algerian novelist Boualem Sansal on Wednesday, releasing him after a year-long imprisonment that sparked widespread criticism.
items.content: Algeria ’s president granted a humanitarian pardon to the French-Algerian novelist Boualem Sansal on Wednesday, releasing him after a year-long imprisonment that sparked widespread criticism.

ai_summary: Algeria pardoned French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal.
Sansal was arrested almost a year ago and sentenced to five years.
The pardon allows Sansal to be transferred to Germany for medical treatment.
The move followed a request from the German president.

items.title: India calls Delhi blast a ‘terror’ attack by ‘anti-national forces’
items.standfirst: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's cabinet on Wednesday called this week's car explosion near New Delhi's historic Red Fort a "heinous terror incident" conducted by "anti-national forces". While authorities did not release any evidence linked to the blast, the classification gives investigators sweeping powers to arrest people and prolong detentions.
items.content: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's cabinet on Wednesday called this week's car explosion near New Delhi's historic Red Fort a "heinous terror incident" conducted by "anti-national forces". items.title: Pakistan opens investigation into Islamabad terror attack

items.content: The provision, tucked into the spending bill that could end the US government shutdown, would ban intoxicating hemp-derived THC products, including gummies and drinks.

ai_summary: The end of the federal shutdown includes a ban on intoxicating hemp products.
The ban is nationwide and affects hemp products that cause intoxication.
The ban was included in a late provision of the spending bill.
The ban could reshape the cannabis industry.
The ban would eliminate intoxicating hemp-derived THC products.
